awd_titl_txt: SEES Fellows: Interdisciplinary Research on Introducing Heat-Tolerant Wheat to Bolster Food Security
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. Sustainability science is an emerging field that addresses the challenges of meeting human needs without harm to the environment, and without sacrificing the ability of future generations to meet their needs. A strong scientific workforce requires individuals educated and trained in interdisciplinary research and thinking, especially in the area of sustainability science. With the SEES Fellowship support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish herself in an independent research career related to sustainability. This project focuses on food sustainability and security on a global scale. The partnerships built into this project will give the Fellow significant inter-disciplinary training (adding the components of randomized controlled trials and crop modeling) beyond the scope of her current expertise. This is particularly important since her goal is to become a sustainability scientist who combines methods and tools from the natural and social sciences to understand how humans are impacted by and adapt to environmental change. Specifically, the Fellow will participate in an interdisciplinary institutes (Center on Food Security and the Environment at Stanford, and Center for Effective Global Action at UC Berkeley). Also, at Stanford University, the Fellow will gain teaching and mentoring experience.

Climate change is predicted to negatively impact agricultural communities and food security across the globe, with models estimating up to a 40% reduction in the yield of some crops by the end of the century. This is particularly problematic for wheat, which is a major staple crop (providing 20% of daily calories) that is already facing declining yields due to warming temperatures. Previous studies have shown that autonomous adaptation strategies (e.g. increasing irrigation, shifting planting date) are not enough to mitigate the negative impacts of warming, and planned adaptation strategies that introduce heat-tolerant wheat varieties are needed to sustainably bolster yields and food security in the face of climate change. Interdisciplinary research is necessary to (1) identify the most effective ways to introduce these new technologies to vulnerable communities, and (2) assess whether the predicted yield benefits of these crops are realized in the field where farmers may deviate from ideal management practices. This study uses randomized controlled trials from development economics to evaluate introduction strategies, remote sensing to quantify if new heat-tolerant wheat varieties provide yield benefits in the field, and process-based crop models to assess whether these new varieties provide predicted yield benefits in future warming scenarios. Understanding the effectiveness of information transfer is particularly important for heat-tolerant crops because, unlike high-yielding varieties introduced during the Green Revolution, heat-tolerant crops may not provide immediate benefits and only produce higher yields in unseasonably warm years. Thus, the adoption and diffusion of this technology may depend purely on whether farmers trust and receive accurate information about possible future benefits. This study is one of the first to examine the most effective ways to introduce new crops that mitigate against climate variability and future climate risk, which is necessary to sustainably enhance food security in the face of climate change.

por.por_cntn:
Wheat yields are stagnating in many regions across the globe and warming temperatures are expected to reduce wheat yields by up to 20% in some regions by mid-century. This is particularly problematic in India, which is the second largest producer of wheat globally and where wheat provides 20% of household calories for India's 1.3 billion people. Identifying ways to (1) adapt wheat systems to reduce the negative impacts of warming temperatures and (2) close yield gaps to increase overall production are key mechanisms to maintain high-levels of wheat production over the coming decades.

To increase yields, large-scale crop statistics are vital as they can quantify the magnitude and causes of regional yield gaps (Lobell, 2013), evaluate the impact of interventions and policies on agricultural production (Jain et al., submitted), and identify lower yielding regions that would benefit from targeted interventions (Jain et al., 2017). While crop cut data, which require harvesting and weighing the grain in field, are the gold standard for measuring yields, they are time- and cost-intensive to collect and are hard to obtain at scale. As an alternative, global, freely available satellite data can provide a low-cost way to generate high spatial-resolution crop yield information across large spatio-temporal scales. Yet to date it has been challenging to map yields at large spatio-temporal scales due to the large amounts of ground data needed to calibrate such large-scale yield mapping models.

Under this project, we developed satellite based yield estimates of wheat across India's main wheat belt, the Indo-Gangetic Plains (IGP), from 2000 to the present. At the regional level, we mapped wheat yields using a new method developed by mentor Lobell called the Scalable Crop Yield Mapper (SCYM) that does not require any ground data for calibration (Lobell et al. 2015). Instead, SCYM uses crop model simulations to simulate calibration data that can be used to develop yield-mapping algorithms. We mapped wheat yield across the IGP using both Landsat (30 m resolution; Jain et al. 2017) and MODIS (250 m resolution; Azzari et al. 2017) satellite data. In addition, we mapped field-level yields in Bihar, India using high-resolution micro-satellite data from Planet (2 - 4 m resolution; Jain et al. 2016).

We then used these yield data to identify ways to (1) help farmers adapt wheat systems to warming temperatures and (2) close existing yield gaps to increase overall production. By combining our yield data with census and remote sensing data on various management (e.g., sowing date), biophysical (e.g., soil type), and infrastructural (e.g., irrigation access) variables, we found that late sow date was the factor that most explained low yields across the region. This is because wheat yield are particularly impacted by warm temperatures that occur at the end of the growing season during the grain filling period. By sowing wheat early, the crop is able to mature prior to this end-of-season heat stress and farmers are able to reduce the negative impacts of warm temperatures on yield. To identify why farmers are sowing wheat late, we interviewed 2,400 farmers across the IGP. We found that the main reason farmers sowed their wheat late is because they sowed the preceding rice crop late, largely due to delays in monsoon onset. Based on this information, we are partnering with CIMMYT-CSISA, an international organization based in India that is working to increase grain yields across northern India, to identify technologies that can help farmers sow their wheat earlier.

In addition, in partnership with CIMMYT-CSISA, we examined the ability for improved nitrogen management to close yield gaps in Bihar, India, where yields are typically low. We introduced a new fertilizer spreader that applies fertilizers more evenly than the traditional hand spreading approach (Jain et al., submitted). We found that this low-cost ($20) intervention was able to increase yields by approximately 5% on average. We further found that these yield gains could be detected using high-resolution satellite imagery, providing a low cost way to conduct impact evaluation at large spatio-temporal scales. Finally, we showed that we could use these satellite data to target the technology to those fields that would benefit most, doubling yield gain for the same intervention cost and effort.

In summary, this project used new methods and data products to map wheat yields at large spatio-temporal scales across India's main wheat belt. We used these data to identify potential management strategies that farmers could adopt to reduce the negative impacts of warming temperatures and to close existing yield gaps. We showed that satellite data could be used to identify what these ideal management strategies are, assess where these strategies could be implemented most effectively, and conduct impact evaluation of interventions on the ground. Such an empirical and data-driven approach can more effectively increase yields in the face of environmental change.
